jeopardy_round: I HAVE A PREPOSITION FOR YOU

(1, 1).clue: "I shall fix some things she like not--garlic and a crucifix--and so seal up the door of the tomb"

(3, 1).clue: These 2 prepositions are absolutely critical in a crossword puzzle

(1, 2).clue: "'That's a fine death!' said Napoleon as he gazed at Bolkonsky"

(2, 2).clue: A treatment called exposure & response prevention tries to ease this type of behavior, the "C" in OCD

(3, 2).clue: As a noun, it's your rear; as a preposition, it means toward the rear

(5, 2).clue: Get a Nokia 6350, this type of old-school item named for how it opens

(6, 2).clue: The chance to be chief construction grip on 1990's Part III of this was an offer Louis Petraglia couldn't refuse

(1, 3).clue: "...fantastically embroidered with gold thread, upon her bosom!"

(3, 3).clue: It means against, whether in a legal action or a sports contest

(4, 3).clue: In 1838 the section in this state from Centerville to Terre Haute was completed at a cost of $1,136,000

(5, 3).clue: Try the fettuccine with this butter, cream & cheese sauce named for an Italian restaurateur

(6, 3).clue: As key grip on this AMC series from 2007 to 2015, Pat O'Mara helped light up 1960s Manhattan

(1, 4).clue: "She was only beginning to realize... she was... on her way home to grandfather, and would see the mountains"

(2, 4).clue: From the Greek for "self law", it's the ability of an individual to behave independently of others' control

(3, 4).clue: Meaning "more distant than", it also follows "the great" to denote the afterlife

(4, 4).clue: The road first spanned the Ohio River in 1849 when a bridge at Wheeling was built in what's now this state; it is still in use

(5, 4).clue: Pick up a pair of Jack Purcell Signature sneakers from this All Star brand

(6, 4).clue: Filming this Selznick classic, grip Fred Williams turned on a radio & the crew learned Britain & Germany were at war

(1, 5).clue: "'Jarndyce of'" this residence, "said Mr. Kenge.  'A dreary name', said the Lord Chancellor"

(2, 5).clue: Dr. Abraham Maslow worked to understand human behavior by relating it to his "hierarchy of" these

(3, 5).clue: You "go" this "to get" this to make a social situation go smoothly

(4, 5).clue: Much of the National Road was built using small stones & a method developed by this Scottish engineer

(5, 5).clue: Get a 500 sport model with alloy wheels & red brake calipers from this brand founded in Turin in 1899

(6, 5).clue: As key grip on this 1998 blockbuster, Jim Kwiatkowski helped make Ireland's coast look like Omaha Beach

(2, 1).clue: This capital on the Vltava River was once the capital of the kingdom of Bohemia

(3, 1).clue: A white tulip is said to represent forgiveness; this color stands for perfect love

(5, 1).clue: This canvas or polyethylene item is used to cover athletic fields as protection from the rain

(6, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Wright Brothers Nat'l Memorial.)  Seeking a place for test flights with strong winds, privacy & sand for soft landings, the Wrights wrote a letter to the U.S. weather bureau & received a list of possible locations; this small fishing village on North Carolina's Outer Banks was just perfect

(1, 2).clue: WWII code talker John Brown Jr.

(2, 2).clue: This most populous city of India was built on what were originally 7 islands, including Colaba & Parel

(3, 2).clue: Since 1980 the tulip has served as the symbol of this disease also known as shaking palsy

(5, 2).clue: To render beautiful or add fictitious details to a story

(6, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Wright Brothers Nat'l Memorial in Kill Devil Hills, NC.)  Frustrated with the data then available concerning wing & propeller designs, the Wrights built their own wind tunnel & tested dozens of models to see what shapes produced the most lift & the least of this force--the resistance to forward motion

(2, 3).clue: An 18th century tobacco factory made famous in "Carmen" is now home to this city's university

(3, 3).clue: The tulip's name is derived from a Turkish word for this, a headdress consisting of one long piece of cloth

(5, 3).clue: In 2015 Denis Mikhaylov set a world record by running 80.53 miles in 12 hours on this

(6, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Wright Brothers Nat'l Memorial in Kill Devil Hills, NC.)  To provide more thrust, the Wrights used two propellers driven by a bicycle chain & sprocket; the laminated spruce propellers were carved by hand & mounted so they'd rotate in opposite directions, canceling out this twisting force

(2, 4).clue: This city is the center of Nigeria's thriving motion picture industry, often called Nollywood

(3, 4).clue: The tulip tree, named for its tulip-like flowers, is also known by this "widely liked" name

(5, 4).clue: From the Greek for "2 sounds", it's the name of the transition sound like that made by the "O-I" in "boil"

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Wright Brothers Nat'l Memorial in Kill Devil Hills, NC.)  A device called an elevator was placed on the front of the Wrights' plane for more efficiency & to protect the pilot in case of a crash; operated by a lever, it adjusted this upward and downward motion of the plane's nose

(1, 5).clue: 33 high-steel workers killed in the 1907 Quebec Bridge collapse

(2, 5).clue: The Confederation Chamber in Province House in this capital of P.E.I. is called the "Birthplace of Canada"

(3, 5).clue: The tulip is the national flower of this country where it originated in the Pamir & Hindukush Mountains

(0, 0).clue: The last prisoner moved before the Bastille was stormed, this nobleman left behind the manuscript for his most infamous work
